ques: Which provision of CrPC deals with registration of FIR in a cognizable case?
explanation: FIR for cognizable offences is recorded under Section 154 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

ques: Anticipatory bail is provided under which provision?
explanation: Section 438 CrPC empowers the court to grant bail in anticipation of arrest.

ques: Police custody beyond how many days requires judicial custody under Section 167 CrPC (serious offences)?
explanation: Police custody cannot exceed 15 days in the whole; thereafter remand is judicial.

ques: Confession recording by Magistrate is under which section?
explanation: Section 164 CrPC empowers Magistrates to record confessions and statements.

ques: Inherent powers of High Court to prevent abuse of process are invoked under:
explanation: Section 482 CrPC preserves inherent powers of the High Court.

ques: Final report/charge sheet submission is governed by:
explanation: Police submit the final report under Section 173 CrPC.

ques: Compounding of offences is provided under:
explanation: Section 320 CrPC lists compoundable offences and conditions.

ques: Examination of the accused by court on incriminating circumstances is under:
explanation: Section 313 CrPC allows the court to question the accused directly.

ques: Statement to police during investigation is recorded under:
explanation: Section 161 CrPC deals with examination of witnesses by police.

ques: Cognizance of offences by Magistrates is under:
explanation: Section 190 CrPC enables Magistrates to take cognizance upon police report or complaint.

ques: Sanction for prosecution of public servants is contemplated under:
explanation: Prior sanction under Section 197 CrPC protects public servants for acts in discharge of duty.

ques: Victim’s right to appeal against acquittal flows from:
explanation: The proviso to Section 372 CrPC grants a victim a limited right of appeal.

ques: Hostile witness concept primarily arises under the Evidence Act. Which section permits cross of one’s own witness?
explanation: Section 154 of the Indian Evidence Act allows the court to permit cross-examination of one’s own witness.

ques: Discovery of fact at the instance of accused is admissible under:
explanation: Section 27 EA carves out an exception for discovery of fact from inadmissible confessions.

ques: Electronic records admissibility certificate requirement is under:
explanation: Section 65B EA requires a certificate for secondary electronic evidence.

ques: Dying declaration is relevant under:
explanation: Statements of a person as to cause of death are relevant under Section 32(1) Evidence Act.

ques: Summons-case vs warrant-case depends primarily on:
explanation: Warrant-cases relate to offences punishable with death, life, or >2 years; others are summons-cases.

ques: When can High Court quash an FIR under Section 482 CrPC?
options: To prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice
explanation: HC uses inherent powers to prevent abuse of process and secure justice.

ques: Test identification parade (TIP) is primarily a matter of:
explanation: TIP has corroborative value; substantive evidence is the identification in court.

ques: Alteration of charge by the court is permitted under:
explanation: Court may alter or add to any charge at any time before judgment under Section 216 CrPC.

ques: Discharge in a sessions case is dealt with under:
explanation: Section 227 CrPC allows discharge if there is not sufficient ground for proceeding.

ques: Framing of charge in sessions cases occurs under:
explanation: Section 228 CrPC is for framing charge in sessions trials.

ques: Judicial confession to a Magistrate must be:
explanation: Confession under 164 CrPC must be voluntary with statutory safeguards.

ques: Non-compoundable offences can be quashed in compromise in rare cases under:
explanation: HC’s inherent powers may quash proceedings to secure ends of justice.

ques: Who has power to order further investigation after charge sheet?
explanation: Magistrate can permit further investigation under Section 173(8) CrPC.

ques: Confession to police is generally inadmissible because of:
explanation: Section 25 EA makes confessions to police officers inadmissible.

ques: When can Magistrate issue process on a complaint?
options: After examination under Section 200 and inquiry under 202 if needed
explanation: Complaint cases require examination of complainant (Sec 200) and possible inquiry (Sec 202).

ques: Bail in non-bailable offences by Sessions Court/HC is under:
explanation: Section 439 CrPC confers special powers of bail to Sessions Court and High Court.

ques: Approver is tendered pardon under:
explanation: Pardon to accomplices is covered by Sections 306–308 CrPC; 306 is before Magistrate.

ques: Who bears burden of proof in criminal trials?
explanation: Prosecution must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt; presumption of innocence applies.

ques: Exclusion of time for production before Magistrate is governed by:
explanation: Arrested person must be produced within 24 hours excluding travel time.

ques: Examining defense witnesses is covered under:
explanation: Section 233 CrPC allows the accused to enter defense and produce evidence in sessions trials.

ques: Standard of proof for defense exceptions (IPC Chapter IV) is:
explanation: Accused need only establish exceptions on a balance of probabilities.

ques: Section 164 statement of a child victim is often recorded to:
explanation: It preserves the victim’s account early, subject to trial scrutiny.

ques: Testimony of a single witness can sustain conviction if:
explanation: Quality over quantity; a wholly reliable single witness can suffice.

ques: Court may summon any person as witness at any stage under:
explanation: Section 311 CrPC gives wide power to summon/recall witnesses for just decision.

ques: Adding a new accused based on evidence during trial is under:
explanation: Under Section 319, court can proceed against persons appearing to have committed an offence.

ques: Who can order transfer of cases from one High Court to another?
explanation: SC has power under Section 406 CrPC to transfer cases.

ques: Revision jurisdiction of High Court is under:
explanation: Section 397 confers revisional powers; Section 401 details HC’s powers in revision.

ques: Plea bargaining is contained in CrPC Chapter:
explanation: Plea bargaining is covered in Chapter XXIIA.

ques: Withdrawal from prosecution by Public Prosecutor requires consent of:
explanation: Court's consent is mandatory under Section 321 CrPC.

ques: When is TIP unnecessary?
explanation: If accused is already well-known to the witness, TIP is unnecessary.

ques: Burden to explain facts especially within knowledge lies under:
explanation: Section 106 places special knowledge facts on that party.

ques: Confession caused by inducement, threat or promise is:
explanation: Section 24 renders such confessions irrelevant.

ques: Order on charge in warrant case instituted on police report is under:
explanation: 239 allows discharge; 240 allows framing of charge in police report cases.

ques: Default/statutory bail arises when charge sheet not filed within:
explanation: Section 167(2) proviso provides 60/90 days limits.

ques: Non-examination of IO is:
options: May or may not be fatal depending on prejudice
explanation: Courts examine prejudice caused to the accused.

ques: Requirement to supply police report and documents to accused is under:
explanation: Section 207 mandates supply of copies to the accused.

ques: Examination-in-chief must be:
options: Oral and relevant; leading normally not permitted
explanation: Leading questions are generally not allowed in examination-in-chief.

ques: Acquittal for benefit of doubt is based on:
explanation: Criminal trials require proof beyond reasonable doubt.

ques: Case diary under Section 172 CrPC can be used by:
options: Court may use; defense with permission
explanation: Court can call and use case diary; defense gets limited access.

ques: Confession recorded in non-compliance with Section 164 safeguards is:
options: Likely inadmissible or of little value
explanation: Non-compliance undermines voluntariness and evidentiary value.

ques: 'Beyond reasonable doubt' means:
options: High degree of probability excluding reasonable doubt
explanation: It is higher than civil standard, not absolute certainty.

ques: Remedy against acquittal by Magistrate for the State lies under:
explanation: State can appeal against acquittal under Section 378 CrPC.

ques: Confession of co-accused under Section 30 EA is:
explanation: Co-accused confession can be used for limited corroboration.

ques: Grant of pardon to an accomplice after commitment is under:
explanation: After commitment, power lies with the court to which the case is committed (S.307).

ques: A confession must be recorded by Magistrate to be:
options: Voluntary and with warnings about consequences
explanation: Magistrate must ensure voluntariness and caution the maker.

ques: Acquittal under Section 232 CrPC occurs when:
options: Prosecution evidence closes and no evidence of guilt
explanation: If no evidence to hold the accused guilty appears, acquittal follows.

ques: Jurisdiction of civil courts is laid down in CPC under:
explanation: Section 9 CPC confers jurisdiction unless barred.

ques: Rejection of plaint is under:
explanation: O7 R11 provides grounds like no cause of action, undervaluation, etc.

ques: Res judicata is codified in:
explanation: Section 11 CPC bars re-litigation of finally decided issues.

ques: Temporary injunctions are governed by:
explanation: O39 allows interim injunctions on prima facie case, balance of convenience, and irreparable injury.

ques: Amendment of pleadings is provided under:
explanation: O6 R17 permits amendment when necessary for deciding the real controversy.

ques: Stay of suit is under:
explanation: Section 10 CPC prevents parallel trials of identical matters.

ques: Notice to government before suit is required by:
explanation: Section 80 mandates a two-month notice in suits against Government/public officers.

ques: Ex parte decree can be set aside under:
explanation: O9 R13 provides remedy on sufficient cause for non-appearance.

ques: Summary suit is filed under:
explanation: O37 enables quick disposal of suits on negotiable instruments, written contracts etc.

ques: Power of court to transfer suits is under:
explanation: Section 24 CPC allows High Court/District Court to transfer or withdraw suits.

ques: Discovery and interrogatories fall under:
explanation: Order XI governs discovery, inspection, and interrogatories.

ques: Judgment on admissions is under:
explanation: O12 R6 allows judgment based on clear admissions.

ques: Withdrawal of suit with liberty to file fresh is under:
explanation: Court may grant liberty if suit suffers from formal defect or other sufficient grounds.

ques: Execution of decrees is provided in:
explanation: Order XXI governs execution procedures.

ques: Mesne profits are typically awarded for:
explanation: They compensate for wrongful occupation of property.

ques: Condonation of delay in limitation is under:
explanation: Section 5 permits delay condonation for sufficient cause (except suits).

ques: Exclusion of time spent prosecuting in wrong forum is under:
explanation: Section 14 excludes time for bona fide proceedings in the wrong forum.

ques: Specific performance is governed by:
explanation: SRA provides remedies like specific performance and injunctions.

ques: Doctrine of res sub judice prevents:
options: Parallel civil trial of same matter between same parties
explanation: Section 10 CPC covers res sub judice.

ques: Necessary and proper parties are handled under:
explanation: Court may strike out/add parties for complete adjudication.

ques: Temporary injunction requires:
options: Prima facie case, balance of convenience, irreparable injury
explanation: The classic threefold test.

ques: Order XXXVIII deals with:
explanation: O38 provides preventive measures to secure decrees.

ques: Review of judgment is under CPC:
explanation: O47 allows review on discovery of new evidence/error apparent.

ques: Second appeal to High Court lies on:
explanation: Section 100 CPC restricts to substantial questions of law.

ques: Order of return of plaint for presentation to proper court is under:
explanation: O7 R10 provides return when the court lacks jurisdiction.

ques: Doctrine of constructive res judicata is in Explanation to:
explanation: Expl. IV to Section 11 CPC deems matters that ought to have been raised as decided.

ques: Appeal from original decree is:
explanation: Section 96 provides first appeals from original decrees.

ques: Revision to High Court is under:
explanation: Section 115 CPC confers revisional jurisdiction on High Courts.

ques: Ad interim ex parte injunction requires:
explanation: Granted in urgent cases with reasons and quick post-order hearing.

ques: Order XX Rule 1 CPC deals with:
explanation: It prescribes pronouncement of judgment and preparation of decree.

ques: Order XIII-A CPC (commercial courts) provides:
explanation: O13-A enables summary judgment in commercial disputes.

ques: Doctrine of election in civil remedies means:
explanation: A party cannot pursue mutually inconsistent remedies simultaneously.

ques: Interim mandatory injunction test is:
explanation: Courts require a higher degree of assurance for mandatory interim orders.

ques: Order XXVI CPC deals with:
explanation: Commissions for examination, local investigations, etc.

ques: Court fee insufficiency leads to:
explanation: Courts usually permit rectification before drastic steps.

ques: Order XII Rule 1 CPC provides:
explanation: It enables requests to admit facts/documents.

ques: Restitution is covered by:
explanation: Restores parties to the position but for the decree/order reversed.

ques: Execution can be filed where:
explanation: CPC permits transfer of decree for execution based on JD's residence/property.

ques: Order XXIII Rule 3 CPC deals with:
explanation: Compromise decree must be lawful and recorded.

ques: Order I Rule 8 CPC enables:
explanation: Permits one or more to sue/defend on behalf of numerous persons with same interest.

ques: Section 89 CPC encourages:
explanation: Refers parties to arbitration, conciliation, mediation, or Lok Adalat.

ques: Order XIV CPC concerns:
explanation: Settlement and framing of issues for trial.

ques: Commercial Courts Act primarily aims to:
explanation: It streamlines high-value commercial litigation.

ques: Order XV-A CPC (varied by states) often provides:
options: Striking off defense for non-deposit (tenancy suits)
explanation: Commonly used in rent matters to compel timely deposit.

ques: Order XX Rule 12 CPC deals with:
explanation: Decrees for possession and mesne profits.

ques: Order XXIX CPC governs suits by/against:
explanation: Deals with corporate litigants' representation.

ques: Order XXXII CPC concerns:
options: Minors and persons of unsound mind
explanation: Provides safeguards like next friend/guardian ad litem.

ques: Order XXXIII CPC enables suits by:
explanation: Permits filing without paying court fee initially.

ques: Order XX Rule 20 CPC provides for:
explanation: Contains forms for mortgage decrees.

ques: Which Article guarantees equality before law and equal protection of laws?
explanation: Article 14 is the equality clause.

ques: Remedy for enforcement of Fundamental Rights lies under:
explanation: Article 32 allows direct approach to Supreme Court.

ques: Writ jurisdiction of High Courts is under:
explanation: Article 226 empowers High Courts to issue writs.

ques: Which part contains Directive Principles of State Policy?
explanation: DPSPs are in Part IV (Articles 36-51).

ques: Basic structure doctrine limits power under:
explanation: Amendment power under Article 368 cannot damage basic structure.

ques: Right to life and personal liberty is under:
explanation: Article 21 has been widely expanded by judicial interpretation.

ques: Which Article defines ‘law’ for the purpose of FR invalidation?
explanation: Article 13 declares laws inconsistent with FRs void.

ques: Which Article deals with prohibition of discrimination on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth?
explanation: Article 15 forbids discrimination; Article 16 ensures equality in public employment.

ques: Freedom of speech and expression is a right under:
explanation: Part of the six freedoms under Article 19(1).

ques: Reasonable restrictions on Article 19(1)(a) are in:
explanation: Grounds include security of the State, public order, decency, etc.

ques: Right to constitutional remedies is itself a:
explanation: Article 32 is a fundamental right.

ques: Abolition of untouchability is under:
explanation: Article 17 declares untouchability abolished.

ques: Which Article provides free and compulsory education for children 6–14 years?
explanation: 21A was inserted by the 86th Amendment.

ques: Right to property now is a:
explanation: Article 300A protects property as a constitutional (not fundamental) right.

ques: Ordinance-making power of the President is under:
explanation: Article 123 allows ordinances when Parliament is not in session.

ques: Special Leave to Appeal to Supreme Court is under:
explanation: Article 136 confers wide SLP jurisdiction.

ques: Emergency due to war/external aggression/armed rebellion is under:
explanation: National emergency is under Article 352.

ques: Financial emergency is provided in:
explanation: Article 360 has never been invoked in India.

ques: President’s Rule in states is under:
explanation: Article 356 deals with failure of constitutional machinery in states.

ques: Basic structure includes:
options: Judicial review, rule of law, separation of powers
explanation: Identified through case law like Kesavananda Bharati and later cases.

ques: Article 131 confers Supreme Court’s:
explanation: Original jurisdiction over certain federal disputes.

ques: Preamble is:
explanation: It guides constitutional interpretation though not enforceable alone.

ques: Fundamental Duties are in:
explanation: Part IVA (Article 51A) lists Fundamental Duties.

ques: Article 19(1)(g) guarantees:
options: Right to practice any profession or trade
explanation: Subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(6).

ques: Judicial review expressly recognized in:
options: All of the above in effect
explanation: Articles 13, 32 and 226 together establish review framework.

ques: Right to privacy is recognized as part of:
explanation: Declared in Puttaswamy; intrinsic to Article 21.

ques: Article 25 provides:
explanation: Subject to public order, morality, health and other FRs.

ques: Article 32 is sometimes called:
options: Heart and soul of the Constitution
explanation: As described by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar.

ques: Article 39(b) and (c) aim at:
options: Distributive justice and preventing concentration of wealth
explanation: Core socialist DPSPs.

ques: Which Article gives Parliament power to form new states?
explanation: Article 3 with President’s recommendation and state views.

ques: Money Bill certification lies with:
explanation: Speaker’s decision is final.

ques: Article 50 directs separation of:
explanation: A DPSP for independent judiciary at subordinate level.

ques: Article 19(2) allows restriction on speech for:
options: Public order and decency among others
explanation: Enumerated grounds under 19(2).

ques: Directive Principles are:
explanation: They guide governance but are not enforceable in courts.

ques: Anti-defection law is in the Tenth Schedule and Article:
explanation: Membership disqualifications tie to Tenth Schedule.

ques: Article 239AA relates to:
explanation: Special status provisions for Delhi.

ques: Reservation in promotion is enabled by:
explanation: 16(4A) permits reservation in promotions for SC/ST subject to conditions.

ques: Article 131 jurisdiction is:
explanation: Original jurisdiction over Centre-State disputes.

ques: Judges of Supreme Court are appointed under:
explanation: Article 124 concerns SC composition and appointments.

ques: Freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse is under:
explanation: Part XIII governs trade and commerce within India.

ques: Article 300A requires:
options: No deprivation of property save by authority of law
explanation: Property is a constitutional right requiring lawful deprivation.

ques: Which Article provides language of Supreme Court proceedings?
explanation: Article 348: English until Parliament provides otherwise.

ques: Article 19(1)(d) guarantees:
explanation: Freedom of movement is protected subject to reasonable restrictions.

ques: Writ of Habeas Corpus is for:
explanation: A high-speed remedy against illegal detention.

ques: Which Article empowers SC to do complete justice?
explanation: Article 142 enables passing any order for complete justice.

ques: Doctrine of pith and substance addresses:
explanation: Looks at true nature of legislation in federal distribution.

ques: Article 13(2) prohibits the State from making laws that:
options: Take away or abridge Fundamental Rights
explanation: Such laws are void to the extent of contravention.

ques: Article 19(1)(c) protects:
explanation: Subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(4).

ques: Secularism as basic structure means:
explanation: Equal respect and non-discrimination among faiths.

ques: Common intention is embodied in:
explanation: Section 34 attributes liability when acts are done in furtherance of common intention.

ques: Criminal conspiracy is under:
explanation: 120A defines, 120B punishes conspiracy.

ques: Murder is punished under:
explanation: Section 302 prescribes punishment for murder.

ques: Culpable homicide not amounting to murder punishment lies in:
explanation: Section 304 has Part I and II based on intention/knowledge.

ques: Dowry death is under:
explanation: Section 304B deals with dowry deaths within 7 years of marriage with dowry cruelty.

ques: Attempt to murder is:
explanation: Section 307 punishes attempt to murder.

ques: Cheating is defined in:
explanation: 415 defines cheating; 420 prescribes aggravated punishment for cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property.

ques: Theft is punished under:
explanation: 378 defines theft; 379 punishes it.

ques: Grievous hurt is defined in:
explanation: Section 320 lists eight kinds of grievous hurt.

ques: Outraging modesty of a woman is under:
explanation: Section 354 deals with assault or criminal force to a woman with intent to outrage her modesty.

ques: Rape definition is in:
explanation: Section 375 defines rape; 376 provides punishment categories.

ques: Bigamy by a married person is under:
explanation: Section 494 punishes marrying again during lifetime of spouse.

ques: Criminal breach of trust is:
explanation: 405 defines; 406 punishes; 409 is aggravated for public servants, bankers etc.

ques: Common object of unlawful assembly is under:
explanation: Section 141 defines unlawful assembly and common object.

ques: Liability for acts done by members of unlawful assembly:
explanation: Section 149 creates constructive liability for common object.

ques: Insanity defense is under:
explanation: Section 84 embodies the McNaughten rule.

ques: Causing death by rash or negligent act is:
explanation: Section 304A addresses rash or negligent acts not amounting to culpable homicide.

ques: Abetment is defined in:
explanation: 107 defines abetment; 109 punishes where no express provision exists.

ques: Kidnapping from lawful guardianship is:
explanation: 361 defines; 363 punishes kidnapping.

ques: Attempt is generally punished under:
explanation: 511 provides general provision where no express attempt punishment exists.

ques: Sedition (as worded in IPC) is in:
explanation: Section 124A contains the offence historically described as sedition.

ques: Forgery is defined under:
explanation: 463 defines; 465 punishes; 468 for cheating-related forgery; 471 for using forged doc.

ques: Criminal intimidation is under:
explanation: 503 defines; 506 punishes criminal intimidation.

ques: Consent given under fear of injury is:
explanation: Section 90 explains what is not consent.

ques: Hurt is defined in:
explanation: Section 319 defines hurt; 323 punishes.

ques: Abetment of suicide is punished under:
explanation: Section 306 deals with abetment of suicide.

ques: House-trespass is:
explanation: 442 defines house-trespass; 448 punishes; 452 aggravated with preparation for hurt etc.

ques: Extortion is defined in:
explanation: 383 defines; 384 punishes extortion.

ques: Mischief is defined in:
explanation: 425 defines mischief; 426–440 contain punishments and aggravated forms.

ques: Rape punishment provisions are primarily in:
explanation: 376 series (including 376AB, 376DA, 376DB, etc.) specify punishments.

ques: Voyeurism is punished under:
explanation: 354C addresses voyeurism; 354D stalking.

ques: Using as genuine a forged document is:
explanation: 471 punishes using a forged document as genuine.

ques: Dishonest misappropriation of property is:
explanation: 403 punishes dishonest misappropriation or conversion.

ques: Harbouring offender is punished under:
explanation: 212 punishes harbouring an offender.

ques: Giving false evidence is:
explanation: 191 defines; 193 punishes false evidence.

ques: Rash driving on a public way is:
explanation: 279 punishes rash driving; may combine with 337/338/304A depending on harm.

ques: Obscenity is addressed in IPC under:
explanation: 292 deals with sale etc. of obscene books; 294 with obscene acts/songs in public.

ques: House-breaking by night is:
explanation: 457 punishes lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night.

ques: Criminal force is defined in:
explanation: 350 defines criminal force; 351 defines assault.

ques: Defamation is:
explanation: 499 defines defamation; 500 punishes it.

ques: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property is:
explanation: 420 is the aggravated form of cheating.

ques: Kidnapping vs abduction distinction rests on:
explanation: Kidnapping is removing a minor/unsound mind; abduction involves force/deceit irrespective of age.

ques: Cruelty by husband/relatives is:
explanation: 498A punishes cruelty to a married woman.

ques: Causing disappearance of evidence is:
explanation: 201 punishes screening offenders and destroying evidence.

ques: Right of private defense is in Sections:
explanation: Chapter IV covers general exceptions including private defense.

ques: Receiving stolen property is:
explanation: 411 punishes dishonestly receiving stolen property.

ques: Housetrespass after preparation for hurt etc. is:
explanation: 452 is aggravated form of house-trespass.
